The San Jose McEnery Convention Center sits in the center of Downtown and boasts hundreds of varied events a year. It has been the home for the OCP Global Summit for over 8 years! The 550,000-square-foot facility is the largest convention center in Silicon Valley. It is named after Tom McEnery, a former Mayor of San Jose. The interactive public art installation "Idea Tree" stands at the front of the Center. 

San Jose is the first convention center in Northern California to receive the cleaning industry’s only outbreak prevention, response and recovery accreditation. Global Biorisk Advisory Council (GBAC) STAR establishes protocols and procedures, offers expert-led training and assesses a facility’s preparedness for biorisk situations. Every venue that receives the accreditation is vetted by GBAC as meeting all requirements for a safe, preventative, and responsive meetings facility.

title: Reduce the Carbon Footprint of Your Cloud-Native Workloads
description: Cloud-native applications have come of age. Most companies making the shift to hybrid clouds, containers and Kubernetes are seeking a range of productivity improvements, resource efficiency, portability and increased scalability. For years, the largest hyperscale cloud providers have been driving significantly better results and operational savings from both their hardware and software stacks by adopting open hardware architecture alongside open source software. Now these gains are readily available to enterprise and hybrid cloud computing customers everywhere. We will address how hardware-plus-software solutions using high- density and high-efficiency OCP hardware, software-defined storage and software-defined networking enable hybrid cloud Kubernetes clusters. With the addition of Azure ARC and Google Anthos, these solutions straddle public and private clouds in a flexible way, all managed from a coherent set of self-service dashboards.

speakers.title: Director, Product Management
speakers.bio: Ynema “Y” Mangum, Product Management Director at ITRenew, has product management and solutions architecture experience in vanity hardware and proprietary software, including compute, storage, converged systems, and private and public cloud solutions. Her experience enables a fresh take on Open Compute and sustainable IT, including how we can underpin even proprietary platforms with Open solutions to benefit everyone.

speakers.title: VP of Sustainability
speakers.bio: Fahmida leads sustainability initiatives for ITRenew, Inc specializing in a global circular economy model for data centers. She spearheads cross-functional efforts to: 1) evaluate supply chain carbon footprint, 2) reduce the company’s footprint through solutions and 3) integrate sustainability and Environmental-Social-Governance (ESG) best practices to create zero carbon-zero waste- circular framework. Prior to returning to high tech in 2021, Fahmida served as a pioneering practitioner in integrating sustainability in higher Education for 15 years. She directed Stanford University’s Office of Sustainability (sustainable.stanford.edu) programs for infrastructure, resource efficiency, assessments, business digitization, individual engagement, and research integration. Fahmida is the founding director at UC Berkeley, where she built its first climate action program and a model for the University of California system in 2007.

title: Executive Talk - AI/ML Metaverse - Presented by Samsung
description: The Metaverse is an exciting world where reality and virtuality meet. It will require new technologies and new ways of using existing technologies. While some of the technologies are obvious, the richness of this world will require many technologies. What impact will this have to OCP?   Samsung Senior Director Young Paik will discuss some of the different ways that the Metaverse can impact OCP server and storage designs, including AI/ML systems.

speakers.title: Sr Director

Young Paik is a Senior Director in Product Planning at Samsung Semiconductor, Inc. He works with a variety of flash and DRAM technologies that are focused on Artificial Intelligence and Business Intelligence. Young’s current responsibilities are in new use cases that push the limits of the boundaries of modern hardware and software. He has a long history working for Silicon Valley startups, specializing in technologies related to: databases, numerical and legal analytics, data visualization, cloud, and data centers.

title: Executive Talk - Challenges and Opportunities in DC-scale AI Cluster Design: Meta case study - Presented by Meta
description: The continued growth of AI, necessitates highly scalable hardware and software to support the rapidly increasing requirements for training deep learning models. This is best addressed by HW/SW co-design, tightly coupling the HW design with the high-performance SW stack. We introduce the DC-scale AI training cluster built using the new extensible ZionEX platform along with the PyTorch based high-performance training stack. This co-designed HW/SW solution enables more than an order of magnitude speedup in end-to-end training throughput and training platform capability for our production use cases.

title: Executive Talk -Google’s Open-source Activities at OCP such as Hyperstack for Datacenter-ready Integrated System (DC-Stack) - Presented by Google
description: Google is committed to open-source solutions within OCP. This year, we will highlight areas of contribution focus such as OpenBMC, RedFish, LinuxBoot, Composable Security Architectures, P4 Integrated Network Stack (PINS), Open Chiplets, SmartFTL for SSD, and Hyperscale Datacenter Architecture. For example, at the 2019 OCP Summit, the Modular Building Block Architecture defined a datacenter-ready secure control module (DC-SCM) and a host processor and memory module. Since   then, we have contributed the DC-SCM 1.0 spec, and a subgroup under the Hardware Management Project is pursuing DC-SCM 2.0 spec. During this Executive Talk, based on DC-SCM, we will introduce a datacenter-ready modular hardware system and a modular software architecture (Hyperstack) to form a datacenter-ready integrated system stack (DC-Stack). This integrated system will serve Hyperscale, Enterprise, and Edge environments and will drive toward the requirements of another OCP Initiative called Cloud Service Model.

title: ON DEMAND: NextGen Cloud Platform using OCP and Kubernetes
description:
When Civo starting looking for a replacement for their Public Cloud and to build the NextGen Cloud, the combination of OCP Hardware and a Kuberentes Control Plane were the clear winners. 

This talk will cover:

  • Requirements and challenges faced by deploying a Public Cloud platform
  • Considerations for DC choice and why OCP Ready Certifications really matter
  • Future scale out requirements 
  • Initial deployment of hardware to a new region
  • Overview of the day 2 operations 
  • Lessons learnt
social_description: Building the Next Gen Public Cloud Platform
attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about the requirements for building and deploying a public cloud. This includes the initial design considerations for high availability, concurrent maintainability and zero touch provisioning (ZTP) and configuration of new and replacement hardware.

Attendees will also learn how OCP Hardware allows them to deploy hardware around the world without having any staff on the ground. The ZTP process means that within 20 minutes of rack power on, customer workload can be running on the new hardware. 

Attendees will also hear about some of the lessons learnt and the changes made after 6 months of operating 2 geo-diverse regions with real customer workload running.

title: Registration
description:
Registration for the 2021 OCP Global Summit will open Monday, August 2. This year's event will be a hybrid format, so we will offer both in-person and virtual options. Please see below for rates and deadlines.

IN-PERSON Early Bird Registration: $499  (Aug 2-31) General Registration: $599  (Sept 1-30) Late & Onsite Registration: $799  (Oct 1 - Nov 10)

VIRTUAL Virtual - All Access:  $199 (Aug 2 - Nov 30) Virtual - Limited:  Free

We encourage you to register early so that we can plan accordingly with any new safety regulations. 

Cancellation Policy

In-person tickets: Cancel on or before Sept 30, full refund. Cancel after Sept 30, no refund. Refund requests must go through the FNvirtual registration system or emailed to registration@opencompute.org. No refunds for virtual tickets.

title: ONIE Status Update 2021
description:
I'll start with a brief summary and thank you for ONIE cntributions over the last year, then discuss new features in ONIE. These include:

  • Upgraded software compoent versions
    • 5..4.86 kernel, GRUB 2.04, etc
  • Debian 10 build environment\
  • Improved support for:
    • Secure Boot
    • emulation
  • Enhanced security with passwords for GRUB and ONIE

...and an overview of handling component upgrade, including:

  • How component upgrade will break existing builds
  • Pitfalls in porting to the new components
  • How users can still build existing software if they do not decide to upgrade.
social_description: Find out how loading a NOS on a switch has gotten safer and easier in this year's ONIE status update
attendees_expected_learnt:
• ONIE manages device software installation
  • Its compoent software has been updated
    • ...which will break existing platform support until they are updated
    • ...but platforms can still build with older code
  • It supports Secure Boot
    • interface points and utilities have been added to clarify cryptographic key management
    • passwords for GRUB and ONIE are now options
  • Using ONIE in emluation is now easier with a helper script

title: Wedge400 -- Meta's New Generation ToR Switch
description: Wedge400 is Meta's new generation top of rack (TOR) switch. It has a 12.8T switching capacity, with 16*QSFP-DD ports for uplinks and 32*QSFP56 ports for downlinks.The ports can be configured as needed for other use cases. It provides up to 8-16 * 200G-FR4/400G-FR4 optics towards Meta's Fabric Switch (Minipack2), and is compatible with 100G-CWDM4 optics towards current Minipack1. For the downlinks, the ports can be set to either 100G (4x25G NRZ mode), 200G (4x50G PAM4 mode) or breakout to 4x25G, 2x50G towards Server/NIC, through DAC cables. It has been deployed inside Meta Data Centers on the latest Compute/Storage/AI racks. It is compatible with Meta's F16 network topology and is also backward compatible with legacy fabric solutions.
social_description: Wedge400 is Meta's new generation top of rack (TOR) switch.
attendees_expected_learnt:
Wedge400 uses the Tomahawk3 ASIC from Broadcom, which has a 12.8T switching capacity and up to 32*400G Ethernet ports. The Switch uses AST2520 BMC on the mainboard which manages the whole system like temperature sensors, fan speed controls, voltage/current monitoring, and Rackmon/Modbus communications with power shelves (PSU/BBU). The micro-server inside Wedge400 is Broadwell-DE from Intel, the same solution as in the Minipack1 platfrom, called Minilake (submitted to OCP in 2019). The micro-server module is a Field Replaceable Unit in Wedge 400. 

Wedge400 supports 100V-270V AC inputs when it's installed with AC PSU (Power Supply Unit), and it supports 1+1 redundancy. It also supports 12V DC input when it's installed with DC PEM (Power Extension Module) in ORv2 racks.

title: PTP @ Scale - Learning from FB’s Journey
description:
The addition of PTP to existing data centers (DCs) is difficult and costly. 

Join us to hear about the journey of implementing PTP and open time-services in DCs.   

The benefits of accurate time-services to applications and operations drives many DCs to enable PTP services. However, with the fast developments around the PTP standard and PTP profiles there are no public references for large-scale Data Center on PTP time-services. 

In this session we will (1) describe the challenges in adding time synchronization to “brownfield” DCs, and how we overcame them; (2) we will define the minimal set of requirements, advise how to avoid major “fork-lifting”, advise how to coexist with legacy NTP services, and how to keep the cost down with TAP; finally we will (3) review the benefits of a pioneer time-aware application running on synchronized data centers. 

Last but not least we will look at future work.
social_description: Join us to hear about the journey of implementing PTP and open time-services in DCs
attendees_expected_learnt:
The OCP TAP references allows adding time synchronization to “brownfield” DCs

What are the minimal set of requirements from the DC 

Design references  

The benefits of open time appliances 

The benefits of time-aware application on synchronized data centers

title: OCP 2021 Strategic Initiatives Community Update
description:
OCP IC roles and responsibilities have been evolving since March 2019. OCP incubation committee has been working over past two years on identifying the key areas for community to focus on. This is a pro-active approach to problem solving within our DC industry and contrasts to initiatives which companies work on to bring into OCP as the case has been over past decade. OCP IC started providing readout of the work done in the incubation starting at 2020 OCP Global Summit. This talk is continuation of that effort to provide the community on update for 2021. 

This track covers details around specific ideas pursued in 2021:

Integrated Solution
Sustainability and Circularity
DC Facilities Security
AI HW-SW co-design
Test and validation around OCP devices
attendees_expected_learnt: This talk is continuation of that effort to provide the community on update for 2021.

track.name: EW: 2021 Strategic Initiatives
track.description:
This track includes all 2021 Strategic Initiatives.

Sustainability and Test & Validation

There are 2 key work-streams being developed under this Strategic Initiative: Lifecycle of Systems/Components and Metrics. OCP is looking for solutions to support these two work-streams as well as any new relevant technologies that may provide insights for re-usability and assessment of environmental impact.

title: What's in the OCP 2021 security checklist and why?
description: The new 2021 OCP Supplier Requirements document contains a Security checklist.   What's in it, why is it there, do I have to implement all of it, and what does it mean, technically?  This talk reviews the Security checklist and what it hopes to accomplish in OCP Inspired(tm) and OCP Accepted (tm) products.

attendees_expected_learnt: The 2021 OCP Supplier Requirements Document includes a checklist on security.  Learn more about the security checklist:  its goals, what's in it, and the technical motivators behind it.

speakers.title: Senior Technical Staff Member

title: Open Rack V3 Design Development
description:
As lead design firm within the ORV3 CLA group, Rittal will explore and define the latest rack design and specification updates. More specifically, details focusing on the design for manufacturability, rack structure considerations and inclusive test findings will be shared with the community. Over the course of multiple design loops, which encompassed FEA and physical testing, problem areas were highlighted and directly addressed during development.  

This presentation will share that journey and show rack design developments. Included in this will be FEA and test results from our structural impact analysis along with an in-depth look at the hydraulic forces on the cooling manifold interface. Especially relevant is the latest latch design and the changes that stemmed from test results. Lastly, development of the ORV3 busbar design and the internal supporting rack beam positioning are to be given.
social_description: ORV3 rack design developments with focus on design and testing
attendees_expected_learnt:
•  Future problems solved    
  • Cooling manifold interface considerations 
  • Busbar development 
  • Latching design overview 
  • ISTA testing results overview 
  • Journey of rack beam position and FEA

title: Application Constraints on Chiplets and interfaces
description: Two chiplet models, namely, system integration of chips into a package and secondly, IO and logic die disaggregation that overcomes the chip size limit imposed by the reticle size, shorter TTM and targeted PPA per function, are emerging. Application performance requirements on the one hand and cost and TCO constraints on the other dictate the feasibility of chiplet architectures. In this talk, we will explore current and emerging HPC and Machine Learning applications and algorithms , their performance requirements and the constraints imposed on the chiplet architectures. In general, standard benchmarks like SpecRate can only provide partial guidance to chiplet architectures at best. Emerging algorithms with features like sparsity can impose stronger latency and bandwidth requirements at the node level and system level which in turn pass these requirements to chiplet architectures.
social_description: Application performance and TCO dictate Chiplet Architectures
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees are expected to get a broader view of feasibility of Chiplets in HPC and Machine Learning Application domain. Constraints imposed by the performance requirements of applications on Chiplet Architectures.

title: Immersion Requirements Rev2
description: This session will cover the update to the Immersion Requirements specification which is generated by the immersion community. attendees_expected_learnt: Immersion solutions need to comply with the guidelines and specifications which are set in the Immersion Requirements documentation. You will learn about how to comply with these requirements and why these requirements are important for vendors, operators and end users.

title: Introducing Open Time Server
description:
Traditionally Time Servers are considered off-the-shelf closed-source commodities. Typical deployments require only a handful of such appliances, making R&D for advanced features hard to justify. Often, you are limited by the feature set provided from the manufacturer. 

The Open Time Server (OTS) reference architecture democratizes the entire suite of hardware, software and management tools to build such appliances with off-the-shelf components and open TAP software. 

By using the latest NIC technologies OTS provides unprecedented scalability and heightened security.
social_description: TAP OTS (Open Time Server) reference architecture democratizes time in DCs
attendees_expected_learnt:
Open Time Server are available today for DCs at any scale. Including hyperscale

Time Card and latest NIC technologies that enable OTS 

The advantages in TAP OTS software

title: FBOSS Experience in Onboarding a Second Silicon Vendor
description:
This talk will cover our experience and challenges in onboarding a new switch silicon vendor into Meta infrastructure, for both hardware and software, and how SAI played a crucial role in this onboarding process. At Meta, we put an emphasis on building our data centers with fully open and disaggregated hardware designed by our engineers and open-sourced through the Open Compute Project (OCP). As we scale up, the need for higher speed switches along with diversifying silicon vendors become a necessity.

For Hardware, this includes board design followed by:

  1. Reusing a Wedge platform for second ASIC vendor
  2. Covid lockdown and program slips
  3. Life cycle of a platform 

For Software, this includes: 

  1. ASIC SDK integration and functionality validation
  2. Open sourcing FBOSS and tests
  3. Tooling
  4. Challenges (SAI Extension, Debuggability)
attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees and expected to learn about:

- Experience, software and hardware challenges in on-boarding a new silicon vendor into Meta infrastructure

- SAI role in onboarding process

- How it enabled a faster path for onboarding a new ASIC

title: Moving Carbon Action and Accounting Upstream
description: Despite renewable energy progress, the data center industry’s carbon footprint keeps growing. We won’t “offset” our way out of this crisis. To reverse decades of damage, we need to take the fight to largest sources of CO2 and eWaste in IT and widen the lens through which decarbonization and sustainability are measured. Join ITRenew, who’s circular, sustainable infrastructure approach is eliminating the 75% of pre-use carbon tied to IT globally. And EcoDataCenter, the Swedish pioneers behind the world’s first climate positive data center. They’ll discuss new solutions turning once-aspirational targets into industry standards for companies like Green AI Cloud (how about net CO2 savings of 100+ grams of carbon/kWh?). This is the next step in carbon modeling: a holistic scope 1, 2, 3 approach that comprehends both hardware and the environment in which it exists. Marrying traditional metrics with building materials, power supplies, and how technology is designed, sourced and implemented.
social_description: Ready to hit reset on the “green datacenter”? Discover the next step in sustainable carbon modeling.
attendees_expected_learnt:
• Why a more holistic scope 1, 2, 3 approach to carbon modeling, that comprehends both IT hardware and the environment in which it exists, is important

• How to more effectively and efficiently reduce carbon impact and increase sustainability

• New solutions and models for measuring and achieving decarbonization and sustainability results

• The role of circularity in addressing the massive amounts of CO2 and eWaste the IT industry generates

track.name: EW: 2021 Strategic Initiatives
track.description:
This track includes all 2021 Strategic Initiatives.

Sustainability and Test & Validation

There are 2 key work-streams being developed under this Strategic Initiative: Lifecycle of Systems/Components and Metrics. OCP is looking for solutions to support these two work-streams as well as any new relevant technologies that may provide insights for re-usability and assessment of environmental impact.

title: Known-Good-Die is at the Heart of a Sustainable Open Chiplet Business Model
description: The talk will focus on presenting the economic importance of Known-Good-Die (KGD) in open ecosystem of chiplets that is under development in ODSA. Definition of KGD set by the SiP builder will impact the Chiplet vendor under different scenarios. We will propose an example KGD agreement between a SiP builder and Chiplet providers to promote open model for multiple vendors in a single package. Lastly, will discuss the test challenges of achieving high and predictable KGD on Chiplets that make it much more difficult than a monolithic die/package. A single bad Chiplet in a SiP with many other good Chiplets will lead to a bad SiP and consequently a high scrap cost. In particular, the expectations of a KGD in a Chiplet-based SiP with multiple vendors can make or break the business case for a particular Chiplet vendor if the vendor is not able to consistently meet the KGD definition set by the SiP builder.
social_description: Is there a KGD agreement between a SiP builder and Chiplet providers that works?
attendees_expected_learnt:
Expect attendees would be both chiplet provider and chiplet-based SiP builders.

Attendees would be expected to learn about the economic impact of KGD in the open chiplet business model. In addition, will see an example KGD agreement between a SiP builder and Chiplet providers to promote open model for multiple vendors in a single package. Lastly, will learn about some of the test challenges that are unique to Chiplets that make achieving a KGD more difficult than a monolithic chip.

title: Yosemite V3: The Next Generation of Modular Servers
description: With an ever-increasing demand for more compute power and an increasing number of application specific hardware types including accelerators, the advantage of modular design is growing to ensure fast build of dedicated SKUs to serve unique and growing workloads. We are proposing our third generation of Yosemite platform that builds on the modular architecture to supports these different workloads, power requirements and varying silicon designs without separate hardware design for each. A common base architecture can use expansion options to customize the solution for each of the many applications. These modular one-socket servers marks a significant improvement in increased modularity, serviceability and a general improvement in volume optimization. This presentation will specifically focus on the improvements from previous generations and how the increased modularity has enabled more use cases for all OCP members and can reduce the total design overhead for new products.
social_description: Modular design for faster and simpler solutions which can increase reusability in server systems
attendees_expected_learnt:
• Motivation for modularity
  • System architecture partitioning for optimal system design for large scale operations and RAS. 
  • Details on the latest generation of FB server architecture
  • How to support many different use cases including storage and accelerators with expansion to standard compute servers
  • Optimization of volume for power and thermal efficiency

title: Reimagining Memory Expansion for Single Socket Servers with CXL
description: Memory and memory utilization are increasingly becoming a critical resource for future servers. At the same time, memory media is not scaling fast enough to keep up and driving more complexity, power, and cost into system designs. In this presentation, we will describe how a new technology (Compute Express Link) will help us address them by using memory expansion solutions. We will discuss the Proof of Concept CXL based memory expander module we have designed, some early results for community feedback, and then share some single socket server hardware design concepts based on the module we will be contributing to OCP in future, and also discuss our collaboration with ecosystem partners to develop a CXL memory expansion solution. We will briefly explore the new features of CXL 2.0 and share how CXL technology is keeping pace to meet the performance and latency demands of emerging workloads for Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about memory expansion trends and challenges, a brief overview of Compute Express Link and how it can be integrated into both HW and SW designs, and single socket server designs that enable memory expansion.

title: Expo Hall Talk - PFC designed to address problem of leading PF, THD and DC content of PSU current in large scale system - Presented by LITEON
description:
Common design PFC exhibits leading power factor from EMI cap because single-ended PFC topology can only produce current in-phase with Line voltage. Harmonic and DC content in input current can add up to more distortion on Line voltage which will exacerbate THD problem.

Design concept different than following traditional single-ended PFC controller is discussed to allow PFC design reducing distortion at zero crossing, producing lagging current to allow system designers of larger-scale systems to program current power factor to address system needs especially while on generator.

title: Open Rack V3 Busbar and Connector Update
description: The Open Rack Version 3 (ORv3) enables a higher rack power density while leveraging 48V distribution. To achieve the future power needs of the next generation of Open Rack equipment, a new IT Gear busbar connector was developed. This presentation will provide a detailed review of the ORv3 IT Gear 48V power input connectors which include a screw mount version as well as a toolless version. The new features of the ORv3 IT Gear 48V power input connectors will be presented which include sense contacts and chassis ground contacts. Also, to be reviewed is the new 48V busbar which also include new features supplemental chassis ground interfaces to the IT Gear equipment through the connector.
social_description: An ORv3 IT Gear 48V power input connectors and ORv3 48V vertical power distribution busbar.
attendees_expected_learnt: Features and benefits of the new ORv3 IT Gear 48V power input connector

title: Extending Network Sustainability via True Distributed Disaggregated Architecture
description:
Circular economy as an economic approach to sustainability is put into practice on compute and storage resources. Extending this approach to the network is not even considered and for a reason, until recently, this wasn’t really an option and the network, monolith or disaggregated, was looked at as a pipeline

The OCP DDC contribution made by AT&T changed that by expanding the concept of disagg from a standalone to a cluster of white boxes running the same network function (NF). Operating a NF over several devices requires abstraction of the hardware, making the network consumable as a set of resources

Use-cases span from core routing as the NF to other routing variants and extended to other NF such as DDoS, FW, DPI, BNG, etc. and the flexibility of mounting new NF over existing infra takes circular economy into networks

Keynote will introduce the concept, example use-cases and OCP products & promote exploring such solutions to the market
social_description: sustainable solutions go beyond compute and storage and into the network as a cloud
attendees_expected_learnt:
How to treat the network as a generating resource rather than a consumer.

How disaggregation extends the sustainability of installed white box based network.

How data and control plane decoupling separate functionality from capacity and enables multiple functions to share the same infrastructure.

How to design a network architecture that can evolve with network versatility.

Where to source DDC components from.

title: Relaunching the Open Network Linux project
description:
Launched in 2013, Open Network Linux (ONL) and the Open Network Linux Platform (ONLP) provide a basic Debian based OS for switching hardware.  Over the last two years, the project has stopped accepting/reviewing most submissions.  Now that ONL is fully controlled by OCP, we are relaunching the project with the involvement of ecosystem partners including network switch vendors, software companies and hardware vendors.

Over the next month we will be focusing on creating an official TSC for the project and looking at options, including taking ONLP out of the ONL repository and making it a consumable sub-module that can be used by the many projects that only consume ONLP, not ONL.  We will also be working to clean up the ONL build system and provide better documentation on how to use both ONL and ONLP.
social_description: The Open Network Linux Project will focus on making the platform (ONLP) easily consumable.
attendees_expected_learnt:
How ONL and ONLP are designed and consumed

How ONL and ONLP can be separated and ONLP consumed by other projects

How ONL will be supported moving forwards

title: Precision Time Protocol Profile for Data Center Applications & Related Network Requirements
description:
Industries such as telecom, power, media, automotive have embraced high accuracy and reliable distribution of time across networks. The data centre industry is no exception to this trend. By referring to the IEEE 1588 Precision Timing Protocol (PTP), each industry defines its own specific set of requirements for distributing time across many hosts with sub-microsecond accuracy on a nanosecond scale. They express their requirements through the definition of a PTP Profile specification. The OCP-TAP group defined a PTP profile called ‘Data Center PTP Profile’ mapped to DC architectures to support time-sensitive applications that make use of more accurate & reliable time distribution than delivered by traditional systems such as NTP.

This presentation focuses on the OCP-TAP Data Center PTP profile, timing requirements, clock types, time error budget, and related host & network requirements to ensure accurate and reliable time distribution at scale.
attendees_expected_learnt: The benefits of PTP in data centers to support time-sensitive applications. The related PTP protocol, host and network configurations and deployment requirements to support the data center hosted applications.

title: PANEL: Gearing Up for Sustainability: Circularity & Metrics
description:
Technology leaders in the OCP community are committing to a series of net zero carbon goals, and the panel will discuss the emerging work to integrate sustainable design of OCP devices. A panel of 5 speakers will explain the work and how companies can get involved. The speakers will also share relevant metrics for measurement, consortiums, supplier considerations and challenges in each of the areas, portraying a holistic picture in an interesting and relatable way. 5 key phases of lifecycle and circularity of an OCP equipment (A Rack, A Server, A Switch, A router) will be used to tell the story on how to:  

  • design waste out 
  • select reusable and renewable materials.
  • manufacture with recyclability in mind, disclosure, certifications, and take back  
  • use in the most sustainable way with carbon calculation 
  • reuse with knowledge of all the above, downstream market, carbon value
social_description: How the OCP community is integrating sustainability and a circular approach for data center designs
attendees_expected_learnt:
• Demonstrate sustainability from technical and operational point of view using circularity as a vehicle.
  • Demonstrate circular design, implementation, and delivery through the lens of product life cycle.  Circular systems employ reuse, sharing, repair, refurbishment, remanufacturing and recycling to create a closed-loop system, minimizing the use of resource inputs and the creation of waste, pollution and carbon emissions. 
  • Key metrics that connect sustainability/circularity to the core elements of OCPs operational framework.
  • Identify industry best practices that can be deployed across vendors, suppliers as well as end user behavior that promotes reusability and circularity. 
  • Discuss friction points between current silos in product lifecycle and capture barriers to entry in each area. 
  • Inspire the audience to action and attend the panel sessions.

track.name: EW: 2021 Strategic Initiatives
track.description:
This track includes all 2021 Strategic Initiatives.

Sustainability and Test & Validation

There are 2 key work-streams being developed under this Strategic Initiative: Lifecycle of Systems/Components and Metrics. OCP is looking for solutions to support these two work-streams as well as any new relevant technologies that may provide insights for re-usability and assessment of environmental impact.

title: Composable Security Architectures
description:
Datacenter machines present a multi-dimensional security challenge. They have dozens of fw elements and are evolving towards a composable framework, with expansion devices, owner DC-SCM cards, and mainboard HPMs

The result is a single-machine patchwork of unequal security postures, fw protection capabilities, and variegated APIs that don’t yet cover hyperscaler requirements.

As we'll explore in the talk, OCP’s modular framework is an opportunity to transition to admissible architectures, with interoperable interconnects, and fw controls meeting minimum requirements. Mirroring the composability and interop we seek via hardware modules, transparent and public APIs can potentially enable the composition of machine identity, and its mutable code TCB. Vendors, manufacturers, hyperscalers and customers benefit from transparent security primitives guaranteeing the integrity of mutable code, and underpinning products like confidential computing, and logical defense against physical intrusion.

track.name: EW: Security
track.description: The goal is to improve security across data centers through open standards. It provides specifications for hardware and software on security implementations.

Prior to VMware, Alberto co-founded Archway Digital Systems, which was a spinoff from HP Labs, where he was researching data center dynamic provisioning technologies. Prior to his work at HP Labs, Alberto worked in the HP-UX Kernel Lab. Alberto holds 19 patents and multiple patent applications.

title: Why You're Not Running More System Experiments (And What You Can Do About It)
description:
Complex systems running ML/HPC workloads need to meet SLOs like Job Completion Time (JCT). These workloads often exhibit a "scatter-gather" or "partition-aggregate" communication pattern, for which effects of hash imbalance and TCP incasts become factors impacting the JCT. In our research on these dependencies, we realized that emulating behaviors of complex systems such that of a datacenter is an entirely new problem to solve. We decided to build a datacenter workload simulator, allowing us to do system level experiments and iterate quickly.

In this talk we will share our journey to build a realistic test setup, which was inspired by the OCP2020 "Bringing the F16 Network into the Lab" tech demo. This approach enabled us to streamline system experiments, and led us to work on an open data model describing network topologies and complex traffic patterns. We’d like to introduce these models to the OCP community and initiate their collaborative development.
attendees_expected_learnt: This talk would be relevant to those who are developing innovative DPUs, comparing Clos topologies, need to better understand buffer pressure, experiment with QoS and ultimately, estimate impact of the networking on ML/HPC job completion time.

title: The circular economy meets immersion cooling: an integrated OCP solution
description: OCP members Asperitas and ITrenew have joined forces to integrate individual OCP accepted products. The Asperitas AIC24 is an immersion cooling tank solution compliant to the OCP immersion cooling requirement. In 2020 Asperitas submitted the immersion optimised cassette to OCP. Asperitas and ITrenew will be showcasing a fully integrated solution based on this standard and with the Sesame by ITrenew circular solutions. The solution will be listed on the Sustainability Solutions marketplace and is offering a very high energy efficiency, with minimal non-IT energy, to be warm water cooled and deliver a high output, making free cooling an option in any climate and heat reuse feasible. Integrated this solution will offer a high density environment with 72 nodes that can be cooled with 45 degrees Celsius in the facility without any fans or pumps. The presentation will include insight in the OCP qualification process, optimisation and test results.
social_description: Asperitas & ITrenew presenting an optimised and integrated immersion cooled OCP solution
attendees_expected_learnt:
- Potential impact of immersion cooling

- Immersion cooling, OCP standards and how to qualify and adopt them

- Optimised integration of OCP server solutions in immersion cooling

- Sustainability impact of OCP immersion cooled solutions

title: Meta Next-Generation Network Switch
description:
• Minipack2 is Facebook’s 200G fabric switch (leaf/spine switch) that provides 128 x 200G Ethernet ports by a single 25.6Tbps switch ASIC. It supports 128 QSFP56 ports or 64 QSFP-DD ports when deployed in Facebook's F16 data center networks.  Similar to Minipack (128x 100G), Minipack2 has a modular architecture that supports multiple port interface types. The specification and the hardware design package of Minipack2 will be contributed to OCP. This workshop will go over hardware architecture of Minipack2 and details on key design decisions, including functional block diagrams, chassis architecture, external and internal interfaces, etc.
  • Arista Networks will also present their next-generation system that supports 128 x 200G or 64 x 400G Ethernet ports powered by a single 25.6Tbps switch ASIC, which has a modular architecture similar to Minipack2. The workshop will go over the functional block diagrams and key improvements achieved.
social_description: Hardware architectures of Facebook Minipack2 / Arista's next-generation 400G switch
attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees of the workshop can expect to learn the hardware architectures of Facebook's next-generation fabric network switch, 128 x 200G Minipack2, as well as Arista's next-generation switch following 7368X4.

title: Specifying Oscillator Holdover for Data Centers
description: Time synchronization via Precision Time Protocol (PTP) reduces traffic between data center servers and enables time-sensitive security checks. Here, each network node is locked to an upstream timing reference, or Grandmaster (GM), whose time is derived from GPS. When the GM loses lock to GPS, the GM enters a state of holdover where a local oscillator maintains network synchronization for a limited time. Since there’s no universal specification for holdover, proper oscillator selection can be challenging and lead to sub-optimal PTP performance. A key goal of the OCP-TAP Oscillator Workstream is to specify time holdover for different classes of oscillators corresponding to different use cases in a data center. This talk presents a model used for this classification that accounts for various noise processes during holdover. A test methodology is also presented to ensure oscillators comply with holdover specifications.
social_description: This talk discusses holdover requirements for a data center, including a model and test methodology
attendees_expected_learnt:
- What are the holdover test parameters specified for oscillators by the OCP-TAP Oscillator Workstream

- Overview of model for time holdover considering different noise sources present in an oscillator

- How to compute max time error for holdover

title: The Era of Cloud Native platforms is here - presenting the Ampere Mt. Jade reference platform running Ampere Altra Max CPUs
description: Over the last decade and a half, applications have been rearchitected to be Cloud Native in order to take advantage of the cloud computing delivery paradigm. It is now the turn of platforms to be rearchitected to better take advantage of the Cloud Native software paradigm. The Ampere Altra and Altra Max have been in the news recently for industry-leading performance and power efficiency. Designed from the ground up for cloud workloads with features like massive scale-out and predictability of performance, Altra and Altra Max are setting new records and raising the bar for other architectures. The Ampere Mt. Jade reference platform has been the lead vehicle for Altra and Altra Max and has been deployed at scale in datacenters around the globe.
social_description: Performance and energy efficiency capabilities of the Ampere CPUs
attendees_expected_learnt: In this talk, you will learn about the performance and energy efficiency capabilities of the Ampere Altra and Altra Max Cloud Native CPUs in the Ampere Mt. Jade reference platform and what can be achieved when a platform is designed with a laser focus on target market usages.

title: DPU Management
description:
The introduction of DPUs (sometimes referred to as smart NICs) brings challenges for host management. By incorporating the required signals into OCP NIC 3.0 specification, it is now possible to implement an OCP 3.0 NIC SFF DPU card with all the needed management interfaces.

Security and recoverability are key elements which are now possible on Nvidia OCP NIC 3.0 DPU design.

DPU management requires some new capabilities from the server BMC which are now part of OpenBMC repository.

In this talk I will go over the different management interfaces, management protocols as well as SW and FW recovery flows.
social_description: Enabling an OCP NIC 3.0 DPU management using standard protocols and interfaces.
attendees_expected_learnt: DPU requires special management support for the control & monitoring of the embedded OS in addition to the standard HW management. This talk will go through the methods to address the new requirements using the existing interfaces of an OCP NIC 3.0 card.

title: Thermal Comparison between Monolithic and Chiplet ASIC Design
description: As Moore’s law approaches the physical limit of the critical size on chip, the need for the use of domain-specific accelerators (DSA) to meet power and performance has been increased. Advanced packaging is used to achieve higher integration densities and performance. However, managing  package thermal density is becoming challenging for accelerators and ASIC. In order to understand the thermal density trade off for die disaggregation advanced package solutions (2D, 2.5D, 3D), this paper selects a ASIC die with compute and SRAM as an example. This talk will focus on understanding the change in thermal density of a package from monolithic die to advanced packaging with chiplet die with 2D, 2.5D, and 3D package options and partner with ecosystem to understand the thermal solution (lid vs. lidless). The thermal performance among the different package options as well as the thermal risks and solutions are discussed in this paper.
attendees_expected_learnt:
Thermal package model development

Thermal performance comparison among different package technologies

Thermal solution comparison including vapor chamber lid, traditional lid, and lid-less design

title: PANEL: One Year of Two Phase (2P) Immersion Cooling in the Cloud: Lessons Learned
description: Two-phase immersion cooling (2PIC) is a promising technology that could improve overclocking performance, power, and reliability. This technology has been mainly adopted at scale in bitcoin-mining application with extremely dense ASIC HW. Microsoft has recently announced that it is the first cloud provider to deploy two phase immersion cooling in a cloud production environment using X86 HW. This session will discuss some details of the journey to getting there. The session will also address some of the common specs and requirements that can be streamlined including chip/server/tank/fluid to enable this technology further.
social_description: Immersion Microsoft 2P https://news.microsoft.com/innovation-stories/datacenter-liquid-cooling/
attendees_expected_learnt: This session will discuss some details of the journey to getting there. The session will also address some of the common specs and requirements that can be streamlined including chip/server/tank/fluid to enable this technology further.

title: Dual TOR use case for Single NIC servers
description: DC networks need to be designed to be fault tolerant and highly available. This requires redundant provisioning at the network level. At the leaf level, this is accomplished by connecting the server to two TORs to ensure that the server has network reachability in case of a single TOR failure. However, connecting to two networks can become particularly challenging if the server has a single NIC. In this space, Microsoft, Broadcom and the community have come up with a unique innovation by using a Y-splitter cable which connects from a server which has a single NIC to two TORs) in Active/Standby modes. This ensures that there is no need to synchronize the software states between the two peers. From a packet forwarding point of view, the solution allows for bounce back routing over a tunnel to ensure that in case of a failure of the cable connected to one of the TORs, the packet can be "bounced" to the peer which has the link up.
attendees_expected_learnt: Innovative way of solving Dual homing issues where there are old servers with only 1 NIC. In this case the classic Dual homing will not work.

title: Confidential Compute solutions in Arm ecosystem
description: Arm’s Realm Management Extension (RME), part of Arm Confidential Compute Architecture, now protects data and code in use. Cloud computing enables cost optimized platforms but come with threat to workloads being exposed to other applications and higher privileged software. RME provides security for customer code and data. The architecture supports attaching AI/ML accelerators in Confidential Compute mode to ensure the platform can be used for complex workloads that need extreme acceleration without exposing data being worked on. Ephemeral per-boot keys support memory encryption, providing physical protection for data stored in external memory. Critically the programming model for platforms does not change. Attestation provides guarantees that the machine is genuine CCA enabled hardware to ensure data privacy trust. Standardized CCA, ecosystem partnership and certification will ensure Arm based platforms will be consistent for software portability and meet the security objectives.
social_description: How @Arm #Confidential Compute Architecture protects Code and Data in use for #Cloud Platforms
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about Arm confidential compute solutions. The presentation will walk through Arm Confidential Compute architecture and system architecture enhancements to enable code and data isolation and protection from various threats across compute spectrum. The talk will walk through accelerator attach models for pushing confidential compute paradigm to accelerators. Learn about the opportunities presented for Cloud by Confidential Compute with end to end attestation, spanning a variety of ecosystems. Cloud workloads hosted by different providers can establish mutual trust. Partners building platforms will learn about the ecosystem enablement activities around industry standards like OCP, 3rd party IP, BSA system standards and PSA security certifications for building systems for uniform implementations.

title: SAI For DPU
description:
DPU - a data processing unit, or smart NIC - is a network device that provides end connectivity from the server to the network, and, in addition to NIC, provides means for fully offloading the network-related tasks on the DPU cores (like running the full-blown SONiC OS), leaving the server CPU for the compute tasks.

In contrast to SONiC switch, where the SAI pipeline is heavily based on IEEE and other standards, the DPU pipeline may be more customizable and provide new offload engines for packet processing. For that purpose, we are defining an infrastructure for adding custom SAI API, as well as adding common API for offload engines like crypto, regex, stateful operations etc, that may not be that common in SONiC Switch.
attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees are expected to learn about the infrastructure for defining a custom SAI pipeline, and new SAI API for offload engines introduced with the DPU.

title: PANEL: Datacenters Demanding Future Sustainability
description: Panel discussion with Meta, Rittal, Asperitas, Victaulic and potentially Microsoft. Moderated by Bill Carter, questions will focus on the future IT challenges with regards to the demand of sustainability. How will new technology features support and sustain efficiencies? What variety of technology is available today? On the other hand, what does the journey look like for current and future demand of these technologies?  Potential panel questions: How does a technology make a data center heat-reuse ready? How do heat reuse principles help facilities which have no re-users in their vicinity? Lowering PUE has been a key goal - can we do much better? What is "heat reuse" and how is it different than data center efficiency? What are some examples of heat reuse that might align with data centers? Heat Reuse sounds like a noble goal what are key barriers? What is needed to overcome those barriers? Attitude, Incentives?
attendees_expected_learnt: Listen to experts from the ACF and ACS project groups discuss topics on what the journey may look like for future technology features that support and sustain efficiencies within the data center.

track.name: EW: 2021 Strategic Initiatives
track.description:
This track includes all 2021 Strategic Initiatives.

Sustainability and Test & Validation

There are 2 key work-streams being developed under this Strategic Initiative: Lifecycle of Systems/Components and Metrics. OCP is looking for solutions to support these two work-streams as well as any new relevant technologies that may provide insights for re-usability and assessment of environmental impact.

Also employed as Data Center Division Manager at Victaulic.  Both roles focus on enabling liquid distribution in data centers, using technologies which align with fundamentals of mission critical solution design and business needs of data centers.

Work in mission critical industries started in naval nuclear submarine program, with subsequent program engineering roles in test systems and missile systems followed by 20+ years in data centers. 

Don graduated from the US Naval Academy with BS in Mechanical Engineering, in addition to earning an MSIT, MBA, PE License, and a variety of industry and military certifications.

title: OCP NIC 3.0: Thermal Considerations
description:
Data rates are accelerating, and there is an increasing need for computation power that comes with inherent thermal costs, making thermal management both critical and challenging. When each degree Celsius has a bearing on solution viability, it is mandatory to ensure that simulations are representative of realistic scenarios.  

Design viability depends on maintaining operational performance at an ambient temperature of 55°C with reasonable airflow. The quantified thermal impact of IO performance for key variables (form factor, module type, power profile, monitor location) will be highlighted and simulation data will show the significant impact of each. 

The industry needs to agree on a common simulation approach that ensures viability studies are based on typical applications - neither too optimistic nor too conservative.  Defining optimal thermal performance requires active participation from module, IO, NIC, system and data center architects.
social_description: The thermal impact of IO performance and the need to agree on a common simulation approach
attendees_expected_learnt:
Simulation data will show the impact of form factor, module type, power profile, and monitor location is more than a couple of degrees Celsius. Therefore, it is necessary to reach consensus regarding these variables and other applicable boundary conditions to ensure that simulation studies are done using a reasonable approach rather than by simulating an environment that may be too optimistic or conservative when it’s compared to typical relevant applications. 

While recommendations can be made from a purely thermal point of view, for successful implementation several other factors come into play. In-depth understanding of the current infrastructure’s capability to implement the recommended design for optimal thermal performance requires active participation from module, IO, NIC, system & datacenter architects. This will help the work group better determine the most appropriate environment in which to conduct  these viability studies.

title: Expo Hall Talk - Solutions Showcase - Increasing Compute and Storage Density with OCP Designs - Presented by ITRenew
description:
Join us for an overview of design adaptations made in collaboration with our customers and partners to increase the deployed density of OCP compute, storage, and GPU solutions. By using advanced cooling solutions, high-density and high-performance NVMe storage devices, and high-performance GPU modules, we can increase the delivered density of dual-socket OCP servers by several factors and achieve:
- ninety-six (96) dual-socket servers per rack (from 2,000 to nearly 4,000   CPU cores per rack)
- over 1.4 PB (petabytes) of >1m IOPS per node NVMe flash storage   converged nodes per rack
- over 5.8 PB (petabytes) of >10m IOPs per node dense flash storage per   rack
- over sixty-four (64) GPUs arranged in high-performance multi-GPU clusters per rack. All interconnected with 25G and 100G networking for high cluster-level throughput that can handle the most demanding customer workloads. Clusters are certified with various container and virtual machine software stacks, as well as AI computing frameworks.

title: ODSA: Optical I/O Chiplet for Heterogeneous Computing
description:
Recent efforts in computer architecture are focusing on building disaggregated systems that can connect different types of SoCs (XPU, Acc., Mem., etc.) together using a scalable communications fabric. These systems are referred to as “heterogeneous computing”, and optical I/O has the potential to be a key enabling technology. 

Electrical I/O faces fundamental challenges in meeting the reach, energy efficiency, and bandwidth density, and latency required for a high-performance scale-out fabric. We present a simplex link that demonstrates the feasibility of using microring technology for optical I/O with performance suitable for building scale-out system architectures and achieving Error-free 1 Tbps WDM Optical I/O.

The chiplet contains multiple full-duplex Tx/Rx optical ports that contain all the electronic circuitry (SerDes, drivers, TIA, Eq, etc.), photonic components (waveguide, MOD., PD.) and a wide-parallel electrical interface to communicate to host ASICs
social_description: Optical I/O Chiplet for Heterogeneous Computing
attendees_expected_learnt: an overview on the optical I/O and ring modulator technology and how to use Optical I/O Chiplet for heterogeneous computing

title: MACsec - Securing Data in Motion Without Performance Penalty
description: Cloud and data center operators rely on advancing technologies to help them handle increased demand for both data throughput and data security. Select the right encryption technology to protect against most security attacks, while still ensure network performance, is of utmost importance. Media access control security (MACsec) has become an important encryption technology that is now shipped with next-generation chips, routers, and switches, including  OCP whitebox switch. It brings line-rate encryption throughput for high-speed Ethernet — critical for cloud and data center operation. This presentation will discuss the key use cases and the state of the industry, the challenges of securing high-speed Ethernet networks, the advantages of MACsec technology, and why test must evolve to ensure smooth deployment.
social_description: MACsec enables Cloud and Data center to secure data-in-motion without performance penalty
attendees_expected_learnt:
· Why an older technology like MACsec is now mission-critical? 

· The state of the industry and the key use cases for hyperscalers

· Why testing must evolve to ensure smooth deployment?

track.name: EW: Security
track.description: The goal is to improve security across data centers through open standards. It provides specifications for hardware and software on security implementations.

title: Next Generation Optics in Meta Data Centers- 200G and 400G pluggable optics
description: FB has started deployment of a new DC fabric based on 25.6Tbps switches.  200G-FR4 QSFP56 and 400G-FR4 QSFP-DD are the two high-volume pluggable optics that support the 25.6Tbps switch fabric. In this talk, we will discuss the large-scale deployment strategy and challenges in optics design, specification, validation, and mass production for these two optics. In addition, we will share our PAM4 optics migration strategy, key performance metrics (HW, FW, thermal and EMI, etc.), correlation at module-level and system-level, and considerations for future enhancements.
social_description: Meta 400G-FR4 optics for datacenter fabric
attendees_expected_learnt: 400G-FR4 optics specification, development challenges and solution

title: Throughput Improvements of Hyperscaled Distributed Databases based on Precision Timing
description:
Traditionally, distributed databases relied on logical clocks to maintain consistency. With the introduction of physical clocks, clock skewness became the bottleneck. The race between clock skewness and latency limits the throughput performance in distributed databases. 

In a hyperscale network consisting of many switch layers, the latency undergoes large variances. NTP is bounded by the variance of latency in the network. In contrast, PTP relies on hardware timestamping and is therefore insensitive to latency variance. 

Using PTP with proper practices required, clock skewness can be dramatically minimized thus maximizing throughput performance in distributed databases. 

In this presentation we will raise the case of industry adoption of Timing APIs in Distributed Databases.
social_description: the case of industry adoption of Timing APIs in Distributed Databases
attendees_expected_learnt:
Using PTP with proper practices maximizes throughput performance in distributed databases

Distributed databases clocks maintain consistency

The race between clock skewness and latency limits the throughput performance, when hyper-scaling the latency undergoes large variances

PTP  hardware timestamping is insensitive to latency variance

title: NICs for Hyperscale Deployments
description: Modern NIC capabilities have advanced beyond connectivity and have become a hub of innovation for data center infrastructure services. NICs are also a key enabler for Cloud and Edge computing and we are just getting started.  Hyperscalers would like to see more innovation in this space and have a vibrant community of established and upstart vendors to choose from.  A key inhibitor to innovation is the lack of clarity on requirements from hyperscale environments.  We propose to create a new track in OCP to standardize on a core set of NIC requirements for hyperscale deployments. These requirements include offloads such as stateless network offloads, inline crypto, network virtualization, RDMA and transports with programmable congestion control. In this talk, we will discuss some of the challenges faced by hyperscalers, and propose tracks for standardization.

title: Developing a Mobile Cart for Datacenter Fluid Servicing
description: With more data centers making the transition from air-based cooling to liquid cooling using cold plate-based technologies, an important consideration for the facility operator is fluid serviceability. The aisle and rack configuration in the data center white space requires a mobile cart that can charge, flush, and purge liquid cooled racks with minimal fluid leakage. In this session we present Intel’s contribution to OCP for a mobile fluid cart that can service fluid to liquid cooled racks that use cold plate-based technologies.
social_description: Considerations for designing a mobile fluid cart to service liquid cooled racks within a datacenter.
attendees_expected_learnt: Users and operators of datacenters considering liquid cooling can learn considerations that can be taken into account to develop an effective mobile cart to service cooling fluids.

title: OMI, The Path to High Bandwidth, High Capacity Near Memory
description:
This talk looks at the OMI technology that is an important component in the OCP Server Project.  In particular OMI will become increasingly important for the OCP-HPC sub-project and the OCP ODSA Sub-project efforts to create the serial modular, flexible and composable local memory that future systems will require.

OMI provides higher Near Memory capacities than DDR or HBM, with performance that comes close to that available from HBM but at lower cost and less processor die space.  It can also reduce total memory power consumption and support both volatile and persistent Near Memory (similar to what CXL provides for Far Memory).  OMI can boost the size and speed of Near Memory to support large, low latency, memory bound problems, such as Machine Learning.
social_description: This talk looks at the OMI technology that is an important component in the OCP Server Project.
attendees_expected_learnt:
Learn about near (directly connected to the processor) and far memory (e.g. CXL)

Developments in DDR, LPDDR and HBM for near memory and comparison to the Open Memory Interface (OMI)

OMI provides higher capacity than HBM at near HBM performance

Benchmark data showing the advantages of OMI versus DDR

OMI is a serial interface that enables flexible and composable near memory.

OMI can support large, low latency, memory bound problems, such as Machine Learning

title: Expo Hall Talk - Retail Technology Transformation with Arrcus Connected Edge (ACE) Platform - Presented by Arrcus
description: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the retail transformation with many retailers looking to enhance customer delight by providing omnichannel shopping experiences. As digital-originated sales continued to increase, it is critical for large retailers to differentiate themselves with a unified experience across their mobile app, drive-up services, in-store services, and loyalty programs. This session walks attendees through how the Arrcus Connected Edge (ACE) platform allows large enterprise retailers to deploy an extensible fabric from data centers to warehouses to stores and other edge locations without compromising on scale and performance. The ACE platform eliminates the bottlenecks posed by legacy networking vendors’ limited offerings and provides enterprise retailers with a programmable and agile edge platform with a highly reliable unified technology stack, allowing to deliver new experiences for customers as business requirements and opportunities evolve.

title: Design Challenges of a BBU Module and Shelf Solution
description: The ORV3 BBU spec offers challenges to design, build and test safe robust power storage and delivery systems. The system is based on bi-directional power delivery, low power backplane to battery charging or high power battery discharge to backplane, with the latter requiring a rapid response time. Many of the challenges are hidden inside the trial and error process of burned components, slower than expected response times, extreme power handling requirements, and logic confusion, all aimed at seamless system backup. Getting through the details of the hardware and software design requires simulation, testing, evaluation, and verification, mixed with a few sleepless nights. This is a case study taking you through simple power conversion examples delivering 3kW in 5+1 redundancy to the system backplane, including the interactions and communications. We will highlight simulation and bench work with scope shots and simplified diagrams on how the system delivers 15kW for 300 seconds.
social_description: ORV3 BBU Bi-directional power storage/backup for the next generation OCP Rack System.
attendees_expected_learnt:
• Li-Ion Battery management details
  • Bi-directional power conversion
    • Single phase buck battery charging
    • Multi-phase boost discharge
    • Rapid transition between modes
  • Accurate current share techniques
    • Analog current share bus
    • Analog voltage droop  
  • Precision Voltage and Current control
  • System monitoring/communications and operational mode requirements
  • Reliability 
  • Interoperability
  • Safety

title: OpenChiplet: An Open Source Specification for Chiplet Marketplace
description:
As the “SoC becomes the new motherboard”, chiplets are emerging as the basis of composable SoCs. To enable a chiplet ecosystem, chiplet standardization will be necessary to enable next generation systems. We will present OpenChiplets, an open source spec to seed the chiplet ecosystem. This is the first open source project building an extensible, scaleable, secure framework defining interoperable chiplets and follows the tenets of open source development:

  • Include all the components necessary to build an interoperable chiplet
  • Utilize standard interfaces, whether open-source or industry standards
  • Provide programmability for customization by the end-user or chiplet vendor

Google has a long history of open sourcing development of key hardware blocks (OpenTitan in 2019). OpenChiplets builds on our commitment to share our work in the spirit of full transparency. We invite the community to come forward and contribute to this specification as we work towards an official 1.0 launch.

title: Introducing Cloud-Native Supercomputing: Bare-Metal, Secured Supercomputing Architecture
description: High-performance computing and artificial intelligence have evolved to be the primary data processing engines for wide commercial use, hosting a variety of users and applications. While providing the highest performance, supercomputers must also offer multi-tenancy security. Therefore they need to be designed as cloud-native platforms. The key element that enables this architecture is the data processing unit (DPU). DPU is a fully integrated data-center-on-a-chip platform that can manage the data center operating system instead of the host processor, enabling security and orchestration of the supercomputer, and dense computing infrastructure with its OCP form factor. This architecture enables supercomputing platforms to deliver bare-metal performance, while natively supporting multi-node tenant isolation.
social_description: Introducing Cloud-Native Supercomputing: Bare-Metal, Secured Supercomputing Architecture
attendees_expected_learnt: The goal of the session is to expose the broader OCP and HPC communities to the new cloud native supercomputing architecture. This architecture enables for the first time a combination of bare metal performance with multi-tenant isolation and security. We will introduce the new architecture and the hardware and software building blocks developed for it, mostly (software) in the open source community. We will review the first supercomputers built under this new concept and the applications performance achieved. The session will include a speaker from Cambridge University and from Ohio State university to discuss the system administration part and the first application performance acceleration (i.e. FFT) examples.

title: Universal Quick Disconnect Blind-Mate Fluid Connector Development, Testing and Specification
description: In September of 2020 the first revision of the specification for the hand-mate Universal Quick Disconnect (UQD) was published through OCP Cold Plate Workstream. This was the first universally interchangeable fluid connector specification designed specifically to meet the requirements of consumer electronics cold plate cooling loops. Development work was already ongoing for a blind mate version of the Universal Quick Disconnect (UQDB). This presentation gives an overview of the development strategy to leverage the hand-mate specification to reduce the product development cycle through design reuse. Testing was also performed to verify the design is interoperable and meets the requirements of the specification. The test methodology, results, and final specification will be presented.
attendees_expected_learnt: In this presentation the details of the UQDB Specification will be given including derivation of some of the more challenging requirments.

title: Challenges and Solutions in PTP Based Time Sync in Hyper-Scale Data Centers: A Study from the Network's Point of View
description: In hyperscale the clock tree is shallow but wide. This means that the number of clients (ordinary clocks) need to scale up rapidly if you move down the clock tree. Traditionally, scaling up the number of clients is done via boundary clocks. However, the integration of boundary clocks in existing switches is more involved and requires major changes in the packet flow. Alternatively, transparent clocks can offer the scale up, with the main difference that they can only provide extension of compliant physical connections and not any scaling in client packet synchronization. In this presentation, we will compare BC based and TC based deployment scenarios for data centers and present test results for both. We will discuss performance and scalability aspects for both scenarios and present test results for the scenarios discussed.
social_description: Practical Network Solutions in PTP HyperScale Data Centers
attendees_expected_learnt:
The challenges of hyper-scale number of  clients on clock trees 

Compare BC based and TC based deployment scenarios for data centers

title: Platform Integrity Attestation at Scale
description:
Assuring platform integrity is top-of-mind for platform owners. Hardware roots of trust can measure and attest to firmware integrity, but this is only one component of platform integrity in hyperscalar environments, which impose a number of practical design constraints. This talk gives an overview of Google's platform attestation framework, whose primary design goals consist of providing scalable recovery from firmware vulnerabilities, while amortizing engineering effort across multiple hardware devices and configurations. Subjects of interest include:

  • Attestation policy content, generation, revocation, and enforcement.
  • Representing the physical model of complex platform topologies.
  • Contributions Google has made to OCP-recommended standards like SPDM and Redfish, to enable platform operators to directly verify attestations from a wide range of roots of trust.
social_description: Google's platform attestation framework provides scalable recovery from firmware vulnerabilities.
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the building blocks currently used to ensure software integrity in Google’s hyperscalar data center environments. We will also go over some of the challenges imposed by such environments, which impose constraints on the solution space. Finally, attendees will learn about developments in open standards that support OCP-recommended attestation flows.

title: SONiC 2021 Update and Beyond
description:
SONiC has been widely adopted by cloud providers, large enterprises, switch vendors and ASIC chip manufactures since it was launched in year 2016. It also has emerged as the leading open-source network OS for network disaggregation. IDC predicts the Sonic-based datacenter switch market will reach $2 billion by 2024. SONiC community keeps adding innovations to the stack to meet the diverse and increasingly demanding needs from different partners and cloud providers to build up a hyper-scale, super reliable open network stack. 

During this session, we will showcase the new features introduced with SONiC 2021 community releases to support Data Center, Enterprise, Edge, Security, Test framework and Disaggregated Chassis scenarios. The outlook will be covered as well.
social_description: SONiC 2021 update and beyond
attendees_expected_learnt: During this session, we will showcase the new features introduced with SONiC 2021 community releases to support Data Center, Enterprise, Edge, Security, Test framework and Disaggregated Chassis scenarios. The outlook will be covered as well.

title: PANEL: Transformational Improvements in Data Center Power Efficiency and Sustainability
description: In this panel several industry, academic, and Government leaders will describe what their organizations are doing and their perspective on what we collectively should be doing to achieve transformational improvements in data center power efficiency and sustainability. Each leader will present for 10 minutes for a total of 50/60 minutes and then all speakers will respond to questions from the audience for another 30/40 minutes. The topics will cover architecture, design, benchmarking, standards, and clean energy. So far, several leaders have committed to present in person including, Tawfik Arabi (Micro-Watts Power and Performance Technologist), Marcus Fontoura (Microsoft Corporate Vice President and Technical Fellow), and Zane Ball (Intel Corporate Vice President), a US DOE participant, and European Commission on clean energy representative. We are still soliciting companies (such Google, Nvidia, AMD), Academia, and Governments and so far the responses are very promising.
social_description: The road to  data center power efficiency and sustainability from Industry and goverment leaders
attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will learn the state of the Art of data centers power efficiency from very well known and respected leaders in their fields and companies. They will learn about the challenges ahead and how the OCP community can contribute to solve these challenges. Specifically, they will learn about best practices in architecture and design to reduce active and leakage power consumption without reducing performance, they will learn about needed standards and metrics to incentivize the cloud providers and raise consumer awareness. They will learn from US and European governments about their funding initiatives and legislation proposals to increase clean energy in data centers. They will have an opportunity to participate and ask questions.

track.name: EW: 2021 Strategic Initiatives
track.description:
This track includes all 2021 Strategic Initiatives.

Sustainability and Test & Validation

There are 2 key work-streams being developed under this Strategic Initiative: Lifecycle of Systems/Components and Metrics. OCP is looking for solutions to support these two work-streams as well as any new relevant technologies that may provide insights for re-usability and assessment of environmental impact.

title: Introduction to the OCP HPC SubProject's HPCM (High Performance Computing Module)
description:
The OCP HPC SubProject aims to create a Modular, Flexible and Composable HPC Architecture building blocks for a wide array of Domain Specific HPC Architectural implementations to be easily realized.

1) Re-Inventing HPC Architectures for a “Domain Specific Architecture” Computing World (10 min)

2) Overview of OCP HPC SubProject’s HPCM (High Performance Computing Module) (10 min)

3) How HPCM provides Efficient & Flexible Interconnect to support increased Fabric Speeds (10 min) 

4) How HPCM’s Thermal Management Cold Plate solution turns traditional approaches on their head (10 min)
social_description: HPCM - The Open, Modular, Flexible and Composable HPC Architecture of the Future
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how HPC Architectures can be radically optimized for Data Centric Applications while maintaining a high level of Modularity, Flexibility and Composability.  This approach yields highly optimized HPC implementations for Domain Specific Applications.

title: Expo Hall Talk - Power Up, Stay On, Run Secure with Open-source Platform Firmware - Presented by AMI
description:
A platform is a collection of hardware and firmware components needed to boot, operate and secure a system. However, most platform firmware is a black box that system owners do not control and cannot change. Open-source firmware offers a unique opportunity for system owners to own the   foundational firmware of their platform. This moves the point of control back to the system owners and enables greater control to modify, change, add specific capabilities and share. Firmware ownership allows them to also own their platform updates, add unique features and more quickly address firmware-based vulnerabilities and security threats.
Open-source firmware requires a community ecosystem to ensure collaboration and freedom to innovate. With AMI’s open-source foundational technology, we are committed to building a community that unleashes innovation and creativity. In addition, customers will have the freedom to use the open base code or leverage additional services around AMI's OpenEdition Power Up, Stay On, and Run Secure solutions.
