title: DDC-Distributed Disaggregated Chassis Evolution (V2): Implementation and Update
description:
The Distributed Disaggregated Chassis Model for Building a Large Scale-Out Forwarding System was presented to OCP in Amsterdam on September 2019.  

Moving away from traditional monolithic chassis approach, DDC was an innovative approach to building large routing systems using commodity whiteboxes built on Merchant Silicon where the hardware and software are disaggregated.  In other words, the same set of hardware can run different NOS for best fit to the use case or the NOS can run on hardware from different ODMs that meets the required hardware specifications.

Since then, AT&T in partnership with key partners : Chip-Broadcom, ODM [UFI and Accton] and NOS [DriveNets and Cisco] , has successfully implemented the DDC vision and running instances of DDC in our network.
attendees_expected_learnt: This objective presentation will share was has been implemented in more details, key learnings as well as the evolution of the DDC Model to include newer capabilities and next-generation chips from Broadcom.

title: Intel Ponte Vecchio Compute Accelerator OAM Product and Systems
description:
Intel Compute Accelerator GPUs will be productized as an Open Accelerator Module, compliant with the OAM 1.1 spec starting with Ponte Vecchio (PVC), Intel’s first Xe-HPC Architecture GPU for HPC and AI. Intel plans to productize x4 & x8 OAM GPU subsystems, the latter built around the UBB 1.0 spec. A key feature of the 8 OAM subsystem and system designed around it, is that it can support both the PVC Accelerator GPU and a next-generation Gaudi AI Processor, allowing system partners to leverage their OAM platforms across 2 Intel product lines, aligning with the vision of the OAM/UBB initiative. Intel remains committed to the OAM standard for future products and is evaluating the new socket being defined as part of OAM 2.0 spec in the OAI working group for our long-term roadmap.

Today we will cover the salient features of our Compute Accelerator OAM for PVC, which is designed for both air and liquid cooled systems and both our x4 & x8 PVC OAM subsystems.
social_description: Intel Ponte Vecchio Compute Accelerator OAM Product and Systems
attendees_expected_learnt: Information about Intel Ponte Vecchio (PVC) product, platform and systems.

title: Open System Firmware in practice: Experiences deploying LinuxBoot and coreboot at Google
description: I will review the results of our four year effort to deploy, first, LinuxBoot; and, second, coreboot, in Google data centers, as part of our Open System Firmware work. LinuxBoot is in use today at scale and coreboot is coming. I will talk about why we have done this work and the advantages that the Open Compute Platform Open System Firmware standard provides.
attendees_expected_learnt: What we learned by deploying Open System Firmware, from its very beginnings to deployment at scale. These experiences should be very helpful to others working to deploy OSF.

track.name: EW: Open System Firmware (OSF)
track.description: An open firmware development project aiming to allow BIOS to be modified and shared by the owners. This project leverages Coreboot/Linux Boot by filling the gaps against UEFI BIOS.

title: Circularity at the Center
description: The cloud industry is expected to grow significantly by 2028, increasing demand for IT hardware & energy. Along with rising emissions, e-waste is another area of concern. For OCP members & industry stakeholders to meet 2030 carbon reduction & circularity goals, we’ll all need to decouple growth from dependency on natural resources, replacing energy intensive manufacturing processes, & minimizing inefficiencies across our supply chains. Anand Narasimhan, GM at Microsoft, will address the heart of sustainability challenges facing the industry & how OCP members lead on climate action. He’ll present an industry vision for sustainability, highlighting key challenges & opportunities for sustainable supply chains, open technology platforms and standards. He’ll share how Microsoft is implementing an end-to-end approach & concrete examples from Microsoft’s cloud sustainability initiatives, reflecting on our multi-year journey, & vision for the years ahead.
social_description: Future of the cloud industry in a circular economy
attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Understand the sustainability challenge facing the cloud/ICT sector

2. Key levers for the cloud industry to reduce emissions and waste, and demonstrate sustainability leadership

3. Importance of taking a comprehensive view and planning proactively

4. Microsoft’s approach to sustainability for cloud 

5. Key learnings from Microsoft’s end to end initiatives to enable a circular economy

track.name: EW: 2021 Strategic Initiatives
track.description:
This track includes all 2021 Strategic Initiatives.

Sustainability and Test & Validation

There are 2 key work-streams being developed under this Strategic Initiative: Lifecycle of Systems/Components and Metrics. OCP is looking for solutions to support these two work-streams as well as any new relevant technologies that may provide insights for re-usability and assessment of environmental impact.

speakers.title: General Manager, Cloud Supply Chain Sustainability
speakers.bio:
At Microsoft, Anand is the General Manager, Cloud Supply Chain Sustainability. His group focuses on innovations across the supply chain in support of Microsoft’s commitment to a sustainable, carbon negative future.

Previously he was Managing Director at Sims, the leading global asset disposition and recycling company. Anand was also co-founder of Voxiva, Inc., which deployed mobile health services across 17 countries. Prior to Voxiva, Anand was the founding Chief Technology Officer of J2 Global Communications (Nasdaq: JCOM). Prior to J2, he worked with IBM, at the Thomas J. Watson Research Center. 

Anand has numerous patents, publications and innovations in various applications of Information technology, Communications, Healthcare services, Business and Consumer cloud services. He has served on various non-profit boards and advisories focusing on issues related to poverty alleviation, education, health and environmental issues in underserved communities.

title: PANEL: OCP ACF - Guidelines for Connection of Liquid Cooled ITE
description: Summary of recommendations and best practices for the  connection and interchange of vendor-based ACS solutions  to Facility Water Systems (FWS) and/or Condenser Water Systems (CWS).  Objectives of maximizing scalability, efficiency, reliability at lower cost and minimal operational impact.   Data center technology refresh happens many times during the life of a data center.  Standardizing connection methods is essential to maximize “Open” use and interchangeability  of technologies with minimal impact, time and cost.
social_description: Best practices and recommendations for standardization of liquid cooled ITE connections
attendees_expected_learnt:
Topics of Discussion include

Design Considerations 

  • Benefits of Standardization of Connections
  • Compatibility with OCP Advanced Cooling Solutions
  • Vendor Product FWS  Connection Standardization
  • Dewpoint Considerations
  • Leak Detection/Collection/Protection considerations
  • Key Components / Functions of Connection Lines  

Re- Connection Considerations

Fixed Pipe Connection Considerations

title: Data Center Lifecycle Management: A Holistic Proposal on Physical Security
description: To date, security across Open Compute Project (OCP) guidelines has focused on information and network security measures. While these aspects of security are critical to delivering and operating secure data center infrastructure, a gap has existed in guidance for physical security best practices. We aim to provide a summary of foundational principles on physical security and general approaches to the development of physical protection systems (PPS) followed by application of these concepts to built data center infrastructure across a range of generalized scales from rack-level to multi-building campus level applications. This document focuses on physical security and is intended to offer a foundational understanding of the topic, as well as to highlight principles of physical security to data center infrastructure across a range of scales from rack-level security to multi-building campus applications.
social_description: Principles on physical security to build data center infrastructure
attendees_expected_learnt:
Learning objectives:

  1. Provide a better understanding of the entire Data Center lifecycle management;
  2. Increase awareness of physical security under a more holistic view within Data Centers;
  3. Update the Data Center community with an outside-in physical security perspective;
  4. Suggest a conceptual framework for addressing physical security under asset lifecycle management;
  5. Provide guidelines for assessing proper physical security measures to enhance Data Center overall security;
  6. Introduce a more broad perspective on physical security to discuss best practices and support knowledge sharing within Data Center community.

title: Reference Clocks in 5G and Time Sensitive Applications
description:
The virtualisation of the Radio Access Network brings significant openness in the 5G equipment eco system. This brings the opportunity for Data Center elements to participate in the 5G networks and deployment. One key aspect is the need to incorporate the timing and synchronisation capabilities to support the stringent requirements of 5G networks defined by 3GPP & ITU-T.

With increasing requirements on the equipment performance, which in general contribute to the overall network performance, demands special type of frequency reference clocks. Adding to the problem, not only the clocks need to have high-performance, they need to work on harsh environmental conditions and to be able to be mass manufactured at cost-effective methods.

 This paper discusses the architectures of synchronisation requirements and the choices of reference clocks that are used to achieve the stringent requirements.
social_description: Choices of reference clocks in Time Sensitive Networks
attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees are expected to learn the following:

1. Traditional architecture is for cellular networks, including synchronisation architectures

2. Evolution to 5G networks, the revolution of virtualised radio access networks.

3. Synchronisation architectures in the ORAN deployment scenarios

4. Impact of frequency references on synchronisation performance

5. Factors affecting synchronisation because of the environments in the data centre.

6. Key Parameters in the selection of frequency references to support the performance of the system, the choices of technology solutions

title: OAM Power Delivery Design Challenges and Recommendations
description: OAM is one of the great initiatives in the industry. SoC node (7n --> 5n --> 3n..) is moving much faster than Power node. With load voltage reaching as low as 0.5V, the load current is reaching more than 1.5KA with peak current more than 2X-4X of that current. The second challenge is the Keep Out Zone required for any mechanical/thermal requirements which limits the area and height available for any VR component. The third challenge is the interfering between the high-speed signal and noise generated by any VR; this limits the area and layers used for routing any power signals. The fourth challenge is the space available on the back of the board due to the connector height and KOZ requirements. In addition, any VR solution should achieve the best performance/efficiency. This presentation will discuss these challenges in more details and put some recommendation for all power delivery designers and manufacturers.
social_description: OAM Power Delivery design challenges and recommendations
attendees_expected_learnt:
* OAM Power Delivery design Challenges

* Power Delivery recommendation moving forward

title: OSF on Intel Xeon Server Processors -- from Blueprint to Production Quality
description:
In this talk, the evolution path and roadmap of OSF (FSP/coreboot/Linuxboot stack) on Intel Xeon-SP ( Scalable Processors: Xeon processor designed for server workloads) is presented. Through multiple generations of Intel Xeon-SP, the industry collaboration on this alternate host firmware stack has been growing bigger, the engineering processes in industry stakeholders' have been solidified, and the technology has been improved to reach production quality in terms of both feature sets and stability.

In addition, OSF has been instrumental in bringing up new technologies. A case study on CXL (Compute Express Link) is presented.
attendees_expected_learnt: The evolution path and roadmap of OSF (FSP/coreboot/Linuxboot stack) on Intel Xeon server processors.

title: Hardware Error Reporting Standardization for Cloud-scale and Edge Infrastructure
description:
Cloud and edge computing management services require a managing hardware from multi vendors seamlessly. Critical functionality includes managing server hardware failures at scale and which depends on standardizing the hardware error reporting formats. As part of the "Hardware Fault Management sub project at OCP we have been working on standardizing the error reporting whether hardware error handled by the Firmware (UEFI/BMC Firmware) or by the operating systems and also standardizing the Redfish schemas for Hardware errors. 

Datacenters today use custom implementations for reporting hardware errors as current standards have limitations. This presentation provides a view into the standard that is driven through OCP for hardware error records; specifically, intra platform standards and datacenter level standard.
attendees_expected_learnt: This presentation provides a view into the standard that is driven through OCP for hardware error records; specifically, intra platform standards and datacenter level standard.

title: Optimizing Performance and Reliability of Datacenter Infrastructure with Alternative Memory Failure Protection Solutions
description: Memory failures are among the most common hardware failures that occur in datacenters today, severely impacting system reliability, availability, and serviceability (RAS). Commonly accepted techniques such as error correcting code (ECC) and correctable errors threshold-based analysis (PFA) have some cost and performance implications and do not offer a proven model for prediction of future failures. Are there better solutions available? This session will explore how alternative memory failure protection solutions leverage machine learning and predictive analysis to predict future memory failures more accurately, while optimizing performance and reliability of datacenter infrastructure and reducing total cost of ownership (TCO).
social_description: Explore how alternative memory failure protection solutions can improve memory failure prediction
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how commonly accepted techniques such as error correcting code (ECC) and correctable errors threshold-based analysis (PFA) have some cost and performance implications and do not offer a proven model for prediction of future failures. They will also learn how how alternative memory failure protection solutions leverage machine learning and predictive analysis to predict future memory failures more accurately, while optimizing performance and reliability of datacenter infrastructure and reducing total cost of ownership (TCO).

title: DC-SCM2.0 Specification Update
description: The Datacenter Secure Control Module 2.0 (DC-SCM 2.0) is an evolution of the DC-SCM 1.0 specification.  This is a collaboration among many companies to create a universal interface specification for a security and management module that can be adopted in various system architectures.  The goal is to allow for future scalability and longevity across multiple generations of enterprise platforms.  The motivation of this effort is to support evolving manageability interfaces, range of entities being securely managed and forthcoming use cases such as multi-node server designs. This specification also furthers definitions in interoperability, discovery and configuration steps above the pure hardware layer.  This presentation will provide an update on the specification and future plans for the sub-project.
attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees will learn:

1. Major technical areas in the specification

2. Status of each technical topic.

title: SONiC Automation: Large Scale Deployments Made Easy
description: SONiC is an open source network operating system based on Linux that runs on switches from multiple vendors and ASICs. SONiC is predicted to become "Linux of Networking" by many Industry Analysts. Enterprise customers aspire to adopt this Open and disaggregated solution in their Data Centers, but a lack of Enterprise class support and in-house expertise have slowed or even blocked them from realising this vision. This presentation aims to discuss the contributions over the past 18 months to address these challenges. It also discusses the integration of AT&T SDN controller and Open-Source Network Operating System (NOS) SONiC.The solution allows customers to adopt an Open-Source architecture powered by a managed service from AT&T with enterprise class support and automation. We will further discuss programmability, gRPC, OC YANG contributions for SONiC by Broadcom and AT&T's development of SONiC driver to integrate their SDN controller with SONiC
attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees would learn about:

• Management Framework of SONiC 

• How YANG models and bidirectional communication with managed network elements improves automation capabilities

• Why having low level access to the chipset via SONiC is a key differentiator

• Some of the technical challenges faced during this integration and how those challenges were mitigated

title: Managing Ethernet-Attached Drives Using Swordfish
description:
Today, storage drives are leveraging NVMe® over Fabrics (NVMe-oF™) technology to create a composable infrastructure and offload servers from heavy storage tasks. Native NVMe-oF is a new emerging drive technology that connects drives directly to the Ethernet network. By implementing the NVM Express standard NVMe over Fabrics (NVMe-oF) technology natively, storage drives enable growth of networked storage capacity and provide scalability. Finally, multi-port drives containing 25G/50G speeds allow for dis-aggregation and composition in Data Centers. 

This presentation will explore the functions and features of the storage device class referred to as Native NVMe-oF Drives and how they provide lower latency, enhanced performance and leverage various form factors like U.2 and the new EDSFF. Attendees will learn about how Native NVMe-oF drives interoperate with other standard technologies like SNIA Swordfish™ and DMTF Redfish™ HTTP based RESTful interface.
social_description: Explore the functions & features of the storage device class Native NVMe-oF Drives
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about how Native NVMe-oF drives interoperate with other standard technologies like SNIA Swordfish™ and DMTF Redfish™ HTTP based RESTful interface.

title: Data Center Integrator Qualification Program
description: Provide details of a new program from UL that is expected to launch at end of 2021. Data center operators have advised UL that there has been some concerns with unqualified contractors and integrators installing data center equipment causing unnecessary downtime and system failures. The request identified a need for a program that identified and qualified installers that were properly trained and knowledgeable of the data center environment and the proper installation methods. The program’s scope , qualification, and certification re-qualification requirements would be covered. Program in the long term may provide a foundation for qualifying installers through certification, and as new technologies emerge and advance in their usage in the date center space, we could include these additional areas of competency thereby increasing the competency of equipment installers while providing confidence to the data center operators that the installation work will be done correctly.
social_description: The program’s scope, qualification and certification re-qualification requirements would be covered.

title: PANEL: OCP HW Operation at Scale - Reliability to Address Silent Data Corruptions
description:
Panel will discuss reliability issues of OCP Hardware at scale around Silent Data Corruptions, that are computational errors with no traceability in HW.  OCP Hardware has been deployed at scale for a while and growing adoption across the industry. The occurrence of this category of errors (like bitflips) was thought to be in the 1 in a million range by the industry, however recent data from Hyperscalers suggest that this is a 1 in 1000s type of problem. Both Meta and Google have published about Silent Errors and Mercurial Cores. This issue in OCP Hardware can quickly emerge to be most troublesome for cloud and enterprise businesses alike. Attend the panel to hear from Hyperscalers, CPU Manufacturers, Academia and more on how this is being addressed.

Panel will cover this category of fault within OCP systems and discussion will also look at ways to augment current efforts on the hardware management side for OCP community to work on.
social_description: Exciting panel discussion on silent errors in the data center hardware systems.
attendees_expected_learnt:
• Attendees will hear from across the industry: from operators deploying OCP systems at scale to silicon vendors providing devices for computation, graphics and networking. 
  • The goal of the panel is to promote awareness across this area of hardware fault in large scale systems
  • Panel will also discuss how OCP Hardware Fault Management sub-project is working to address this issue in open manner.
  • The attendees will hear from:-
    • Academia (Moderator)
    • (confirmed) Sriram Sankar, Director of Engineering, Meta
    • (confirmed) Rama Govindaraju, Director of Engineering, Google 
    • Ian Steiner, Sr Principal Engineer, Intel 
    • AMD
    • NVidia/Mellanox/Broadcom

title: PANEL: Challenges Facing 5G vRAN Providers and Open-Source Solutions
description: Panelists from a range of 5G vRAN Provider perspectives will discuss challenges facing them in the Web Scale, Carrier and Online product and service industries. Comparison of mutual challenges will promote discussion where open-source hardware solutions can provide a benefit to 5G vRAN Providers. A virtualized radio access network (vRAN) is a type of RAN with its networking functions separated or disaggregated from the hardware it runs on. The control and data planes of the vRAN are also separated as part of the virtualization. This type of RAN is heavily associated with 5G networks because the networks need virtualization to support the use cases and performance requirements of 5G.
attendees_expected_learnt: Multiple perspectives of this challenge and how companies are trying to solve it.

title: Enabling Runtime RAS on Xeon OCP Platforms Using Intel FSP and Coreboot
description: Intel® FSP binary package when integrated with coreboot, provides processor, memory and chipset initialization. However conventional runtime RAS services are natively implemented as UEFI SMM modules can’t be directly integrated into coreboot framework. This talk provides technical solution for enabling runtime RAS services under coreboot framework via FSP API interface. By de-coupling RAS service from DXE stack, it is possible to deliver runtime RAS functionality via Standalone MM architecture and Intel® FSP with minimum bootloader changes. This concept implementation on OCP Yosemite V3/Cooper Lake Xeon SP processor will illustrate the technical feasibility with coreboot framework. This talk is part of Intel® FSP exploration to support diversified boot frameworks along with Open system firmware initiative, will cover Xeon runtime RAS overview, traditional runtime RAS in UEFI, Standalone MM architecture with FSP API for enabling runtime RAS in coreboot and working demo.
attendees_expected_learnt: The participant should learn UEFI Platform Initialization Architecture, Intel(R) Firmware Support Package Definition, Xeon RAS functionality and Coreboot framework.

track.name: EW: Open System Firmware (OSF)
track.description: An open firmware development project aiming to allow BIOS to be modified and shared by the owners. This project leverages Coreboot/Linux Boot by filling the gaps against UEFI BIOS.

title: Testing Hardware at Hyperscale
description: The testing of hardware health at hyperscale becomes increasingly challenging as server fleet sizes continue to increase and the composition of the fleet is increasingly heterogeneous with specialized accelerators, offloads, and custom ASICs composed of different instruction sets and architectures. This presentation will cover the challenges present and approaches used to address the growing complexity that we have encountered at multiple phases of a hardware’s lifecycle including product validation, manufacturing, data center service, and reverse logistics.  We will discuss the implementation of telemetry/monitoring, stress stimulus, as well as leveraging newer test and in place repair techniques for system memory.  Finally, we’ll discuss the proposed integration points of diagnostics with workflow engines, intelligent repair systems, and test executives.

track.name: EW: 2021 Strategic Initiatives
track.description:
This track includes all 2021 Strategic Initiatives.

Sustainability and Test & Validation

There are 2 key work-streams being developed under this Strategic Initiative: Lifecycle of Systems/Components and Metrics. OCP is looking for solutions to support these two work-streams as well as any new relevant technologies that may provide insights for re-usability and assessment of environmental impact.

speakers.title: Engineering Manager
speakers.bio: Studying Applied Physics got me interested in robotics and Virtual Reality where I researched and used VR to help people overcome phobias. At that time most of my work involved distributed applications that exhibited high sensitivity to network latency and performance, this led me to join a High Performance Computing research group where I became fascinated with peer-to-peer computing and the study of complex systems. After completing grad school I joined an HPC team at Altair Engineering developing Enterprise grade scheduler and workload management solutions that power Fortune 500 companies compute and render farms. I joined Meta (then Facebook) in 2015 where I designed, implemented, and currently lead teams building tools and solutions applied to the design and validation of all Data Center OCP hardware, including the deployment and maintenance of custom built appliances at labs, factories, and vendors global sites.

title: Introduction of DC-SCM 2.0 LVDS Tunneling Protocol & Interface (LTPI)
description: One of the most significant change in the DC-SCM 2.0 specification is the introduction of Low-voltage differential signaling Tunneling Protocol & Interface (LTPI). It is a scalable and high bandwidth serial interface specially designed for the OCP DC-SCM use cases. It allows tunneling of multiple manageability interfaces between Host Platform Module and DC-SCM module over low pin count LVDS-based interface. The LTPI addresses shortcomings of Serial GPIO interface used in DC-SCM 1.0 by providing much lower latency for GPIO and a possibility to tunnel I2C, SMBus, UART, Data/Custom Channels. LTPI allowed for pinout optimizations and new capabilities addition in DC-SCM 2.0. In this presentation we will go through overview of the DC-SCM 2.0 LTPI specification and key concepts that were worked out by the DC-SCM 2.0 LTPI Workstream Group in 2021.
social_description: An overview and key concepts of DC-SCM 2.0 LVDS Tunneling Protocol & Interface (LTPI)
attendees_expected_learnt: The presentation will provide an update on the year-long effort done by the DC-SCM 2.0 LTPI Workstream to standardize a high bandwidth interface that is optimized for OCP DC-SCM solutions. The attendees will have an opportunity to understand the key concepts of the LTPI interface. The session will provide a in-depth technical review of the interface, it's capabilities, scalability and the value it brings in the context of modular designs of OCP platforms.

In OCP, John is the Incubation Committee representative to its Hardware Management Project. John also represents Intel on the Board of the DMTF standard organization (dmtf.org) holding the office of VP of Alliances. In addition, John represents Intel in the DMTF Redfish Forum.

title: Pros and Cons of integrating a modular BMC design (DC-SCM card) into a server
description:
In this workshop, we would like to share Wiwynn’s three horizontal type DC-SCM (Datacenter Secure Control Module) v1 cards developed experience. Also, we would like to share our perspective about what we can improve in the future.

We would provide the pros and cons of DC-SCM card from the developing stage to the validation stage. DC-SCM card has the following pros: cost-saving, easy to repair, suitable for multiple HPM boards, standard front panel, etc. But there are also some cons: Including layout limitation, the card is crowed with components, with strict mechanical keep out zones, non-flexible pin defines, etc.

We would also share how to overcome these disadvantages in the future. For example, using vertical type DC-SCM card, we could avoid layout issue. We could also spare more interface pins for flexibility using MCSI protocol in OCP DC-SCM Spec v2. Wiwynn has the DC-SCM card designed experience and looking forward to share to you all.
social_description: Sharing of Wiwynn’s three horizontal DC-SCM v1 cards developed experience and future improvement.
attendees_expected_learnt:
This workshop is for the participants who are interested in designing DC-SCM card. After attending this workshop, we expect they can learn:

1. The top-level overview of DC-SCM card

2. Design or validation lesson learnt from Wiwynn, avoid facing the same difficulties again.

3. The pros and cons using DC-SCM card, this could help them to take the decision whether it’s suitable to include the card in their architecture.

4. What they can expect DC-SCM card will improve in the future.

title: Modeling of Data Center Harmonic Emissions for Building Compliance
description: Data centers must comply with harmonic emission standards imposed by local power utilities. In the design of these data centers, simulation is helpful to anticipate harmonic emission problems and to determine appropriate solutions. Several alternatives exist for simulating harmonics. In some instances, the re-combinations of harmonics and the branch impedances are neglected, which lead to overly conservative and inaccurate results. On the other hand, when harmonics exceed practical limits, there is reduced efficiency, equipment overheating and failure, and/or utility penalties. This work presents a new and more accurate harmonic modeling method for data center emissions, which consists of capturing the effects of complex electronics impedances within the data center.
social_description: This work presents a novel harmonic modeling method for data center harmonic emissions.
attendees_expected_learnt: Harmonic modeling methods to simulate and design data centers with more accuracy, in order to prevent costly last minute solutions and network operator penalties.

title: Migration to SONiC from 3-tiered legacy network – EPFL Case Study
description: EPFL is a large public research university in Lausanne Switzerland with over 12000 students and 5000+ staff members. EPFL chose SONiC as the NOS (Network Operating System) for their 3 x Data Centres and first phase of deployment includes 200+ switches. Given the scale of their deployment, Migration seemed like challenging task and there were stringent business requirements around High Availability and keeping the lights on during migration. EPFL, Broadcom and Juniper (Apstra) teams worked together to formulate a migration strategy that would meet these requirements. In this joint-presentation, Architects from the three companies involved will elaborate their migration strategy, some of the issues hit during validation process and how those issues were fixed. The presentation also aims to discuss some of the optimisations used to minimise the downtime and the role of automation in large scale deployments and migrations.
attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will also learn about:

· Why EPFL choose SONiC

· EPFL’s Fabric Architecture

· SONiC configuration suitable for Migration

· AoS integration with SONiC and how it facilitates large scale migration

title: Introducing advanced cooling solutions into existing data centers: Design considerations and, operational and performance learnings
description:
Projected trends in component power and density are beginning to push the limits of traditional air cooling. Closed-loop liquid cooling with effective liquid-to-air heat exchange (in short, Air-Assisted Liquid Cooling or AALC) is an agile option for higher chip power and rack density enablement.

First part of this talk will preview documentation being prepared for contribution to OCP to build an accessible list of compliant solutions. The second part will discuss more on the operational learnings and characterization on an Olympus server-based solution; which include system assembly, characterization, serviceability and maintenance.
attendees_expected_learnt: This session will preview documentation being prepared for contribution to OCP to build an accessible list of compliant solutions. First is a detailed specification for the Reservoir and Pumping Unit (RPU), which serves as the “hub” of the solution, responsible for control, monitoring and upstream communication, and designed for use in tandem with different types of heat rejection. The second document will outline requirements for the overall AALC solution with focus on the liquid-to-air heat exchanger; whether a Door HX implementation or adjacent rack type or otherwise. Also previewed will be the different rack-level approaches to AALC, which hyperscalers are evaluating for their existing data centers.

track.name: EW: Cooling Environments
track.description: This track is a combo crossover track between Rack and Power (ACS) and Data Center Facilities (ACF).

title: SmartFTL Architecture for SSDs
description:
Google has internally developed multiple generations of SSDs since 2010. By building and operating these drives we’ve gained extensive experience with a wide variety of workloads, understand the cloud operations, and possess detailed drive internal knowledge that is normally the domain of SSD vendors.  Google has also paid close attention to the broader NVMe SSD marketplace and assessed its alignment to our needs. 

In this talk we introduce the concept of a “SmartFTL” architecture.  We share our learnings over the years including the complexity of NAND management and the various architectural tradeoffs in designing an SSD around the proposed architecture.  In particular we will consider SSD interfaces, cloud application / FTL integration, performance / garbage collection tradeoffs, and performance / reliability tradeoffs.

title: LibreBMC -- A soft processor on an FPGA based solution for running the OpenBMC software stack
description: Baseboard Management Controllers (BMCs) sit at the heart of the boot and control infrastructure in the datacenter, so they require a unique functionality set.  Based on work to improve open source FPGA tooling, it’s now possible to replace traditional BMC ASICs with soft processors running on low cost FPGA hardware while still running the familiar OpenBMC software stack. To demonstrate this, the LibreBMC project was created and is being run under the OpenPOWER Foundation. Taking advantage of OCP’s DC-SCM spec, Antmicro has created the first ever open source DC-SCM 1.0 modules with LibreBMC supported FPGAs. This allows drop in replacement on existing designs, fully verifiable hardware, and the unique opportunity to do software style deployment of new “hardware based” security features (like memory tagging) even after hardware has been deployed in the datacenter!
attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn the following:

1.  The basic functions of a Baseboard Management Controller (BMC).

2.  The advantages of using an FPGA, along with fully open source hardware and software, as the BMC.

3.  The current functional status of the OpenBMC stack running on the DC-SCM board.

4.  The next steps in the libreBMC project and how they can get involved.

The interactive public art installation "Idea Tree" stands at the front of the Center. 

San Jose is the first convention center in Northern California to receive the cleaning industry’s only outbreak prevention, response and recovery accreditation. Global Biorisk Advisory Council (GBAC) STAR establishes protocols and procedures, offers expert-led training and assesses a facility’s preparedness for biorisk situations. Every venue that receives the accreditation is vetted by GBAC as meeting all requirements for a safe, preventative, and responsive meetings facility.

title: Hyperstack for Datacenter-ready Integrated System Stack (DC-Stack)
description: This is a drill-down on the Hyperstack story toward a datacenter-ready integrated system. At the 2019 OCP Summit, we introduced a Modular Building Block Architecture (MBA) which defined a datacenter-ready secure control module (DC-SCM) and a host processor and memory module (HPM). Since then, we have contributed the DC-SCM 1.0 specification to OCP, and a subgroup under Hardware Management Project is pursuing DC-SCM 2.0 specification. During this Workshop, based on DC-SCM, we will go deeper in describing the ingredients for a datacenter-ready modular hardware system (DC-MHS) and a modular software architecture (Hyperstack) to form a datacenter-ready integrated system stack (DC-Stack).  This integrated system will serve Hyperscale, Enterprise, and Edge environments and will drive toward the requirements of another OCP Initiative called Cloud Service Model (CSM).

title: ON DEMAND: Deploying SONiC in the Enterprise
description:
We have all heard about Hyperscalers deploying disaggregated Network Fabrics. At Target we have reached a point where we need to decouple our Hardware and Software for our Network Fabrics. Our first deployments of an Open Network System for our Network Fabrics has been with SONiC. Many Enterprises may think that they could not make the shift to an Open Fabric with SONiC. I am here to tell you it is achievable. The first step to do in order to make this transition is to take one step forward. 

Come and hear how Target got started on our transition to Open Switching Fabrics using SONiC as our Network Operating System. I will share with you some of the foundational things we had to build. I will share some dos and don'ts when getting ready to deploy SONiC.
social_description: SONiC Networking - Deploying in an Enterprise Network. It isn't just for hyperscalers anymore.
attendees_expected_learnt: They will learn some of the key things to do in order to get started deploying SONiC in Enterprise Networks.

title: ON DEMAND: Testing for the DatacenterSSD Specification
description: The DatacenterSSD specification has been created by a group of hyperscale datacenter companies in collaboration with SSD suppliers and enterprise integrators. What is in this specification? How does it expand on the NVMe specification? How can devices demonstrate compliance? In this talk we’ll review important items from the DatacenterSSD specification to understand how it expands on the NVMe family of specifications for specific use cases in a datacenter environment. Since the DatacenterSSD specification goes beyond just an interface specification, we will also show what test setups can be used to demonstrate compliance.
social_description: What is the DatacenterSSD Spec? How do you test against it? Find out in this presentation.
attendees_expected_learnt: What is the DatacenterSSD specification? How is it different from the NVMe specification? How does it leverage/build up on the NVMe specification? What equipment and test setups can be used to demonstrate compliance to the DatacenterSSD specification?

title: ON DEMAND: Introduction of DC-SCM 2.0 LVDS Tunneling Protocol & Interface (LTPI)
description: One of the most significant change in the DC-SCM 2.0 specification is the introduction of Low-voltage differential signaling Tunneling Protocol & Interface (LTPI). It is a scalable and high bandwidth serial interface specially designed for the OCP DC-SCM use cases. It allows tunneling of multiple manageability interfaces between Host Platform Module and DC-SCM module over low pin count LVDS-based interface. The LTPI addresses shortcomings of Serial GPIO interface used in DC-SCM 1.0 by providing much lower latency for GPIO and a possibility to tunnel I2C, SMBus, UART, Data/Custom Channels. LTPI allowed for pinout optimizations and new capabilities addition in DC-SCM 2.0. In this presentation we will go through overview of the DC-SCM 2.0 LTPI specification and key concepts that were worked out by the DC-SCM 2.0 LTPI Workstream Group in 2021.

title: ON DEMAND: Achronix Speedster FPGAs enabling ODSA Chiplet Roadmap
description: Achronix is a supplier of high end FPGAs and embedded eFPGA IP used in data centers and networking equipment. The Speedster 7t family includes multiple 400G Ethernet, PCIe Gen5 interfaces and 16Gbps GDDR6 memory to enable high performance solutions. Its Machine Learning Processor provides leading edge ML capabilities in addition to its high performance interlaces and memory. Additionally, its multiple 100G and 56G high speed SerDes can be used to interconnect other devices to the Speedster to enable multi-chip and multi-die solutions. This short 10 min presentation will cover the Achronix product family, its capabilities and the potential uses of its interfaces to create multi-device platforms. We will cover the use of standard interfaces such as Ethernet and PCIe for chip to chip communication, as well as the use of high speed SerDes in bypass mode to provide new protocol and messaging options to the user. The upcoming roadmap will be presented.
social_description: The Achronix Speedster 7t Family, enabling ODSA Chiplet Roadmap
attendees_expected_learnt: The Achronix Speedster 7t family of FPGAs and its high speed SerDes for chip to chip communications

title: ON DEMAND: Today’s Highest-speed Options in Cabled Interconnects
description:
High speed cables are critical components in data center applications. They connect switch to switch ports, or connect switch ports to server nodes. Three types of high speed cables co-exist currently: Direct Attach Cable (DAC), Active Copper Cable (ACC) and Active Optical Cable (AOC). DAC is purely passive. This study provides the detailed comparison of QSFP, QSFPDD and OSFP form factors for system engineers to apply them in current and future designs.

 This presentation will compare DAC, ACC and AOC in multiple dimensions. First, design details will be introduced. The achievable reach distance for each cable type will be discussed. The current industry product power consumptions,  thermal solutions, and reliability data will be shared as well. Finally, the relative costs of DAC, ACC and AOC will be estimated.
attendees_expected_learnt: Understand the difference between DAC, ACC and AOC

title: ON DEMAND PANEL: Data Center Operation Technology: Monitoring and Logging for Security
description: Operational Technology (OT) used to run Data Centers, including Industrial Control Systems (ICS) that support building operations, are frequently designed to support multiple generations of IT equipment. Because OT must prioritize robustness and availability, it often lags behind IT in modern security best practices. In this panel we will discuss our approach to improving OT security through a set of monitoring and logging guidelines. By regularizing the data available across OT equipment and how that data may be utilized with a security context, we hope to help elevate OT security closer towards IT security levels.
attendees_expected_learnt:
• IT vs OT security design principles
  • Process for classification of OT assets
  • Criticality of potential threats and weaknesses
  • Event and monitoring taxonomy
  • Data modeling of data center OT equipment

title: ON DEMAND: SFF Driving Future Server Needs
description: For every system, there are connectors, cables, and form factors defined by the Small Form Factor Technical Working Group (SFF-TA TWG) within SNIA.  This group has driven many specifications including 2.5” and 3.5” HDD/SSD form factor, high speed networking connectors, various high speed differential signaling connectors, as well as EDSFF currently in use by the OCP Storage Project.  Come listen to our talk to find out what SFF is doing to keep up with the rapid changes driven in OCP.
attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn what the SFF-TA technical working group has done to meet the higher speeds and feeds needed in systems, changes made to enhance system implementations, and current projects and improvements in process.

speakers.title: Principal Engineer
speakers.bio: Anthony Constantine is a Principal Engineer at Intel, where he focuses primarily on driving innovation to memory and storage from mobile to datacenter. He is active in the standards area, contributing to SFF-TA (SNIA), Open NAND Flash Interface (ONFI), PCI-SIG, and JEDEC. Anthony has over 20 years of experience in the technology industry with an expertise in memory, storage, physical interfaces, low power technologies, and form factors.  He earned a BS in Electrical Engineering from UC Davis.

title: ON DEMAND: DICE based NIC attestation
description:
The introduction of attestation-protocol requires secured-devices to be able to prove their identity and data-integrity in a secured non-cloneable way. ConnectX-7 devices embed HW RoT which, combined with production-time provisioning of device certificate, device-unique asymmetric key-pair and ROM code, allows to address secure-boot, secure FW update and DICE based attestation, while allowing full recoverability and upgradability for any deployed HW.

In this talk I will cover the attestation flow, which includes the reported attestation measurements, certificate-chain and the process of preventing device-cloning. The attestation flow uses SPDM protocol and addresses the TCG DICE specification.
social_description: FW attestation using SPDM protocol combined with TCG DICE specification
attendees_expected_learnt: Platform security developers and platform-SW developer.

track.name: EW: Security
track.description: The goal is to improve security across data centers through open standards. It provides specifications for hardware and software on security implementations.

title: Sponsor Story: FNTECH
description: FNTECH is leading the charge for all kinds of events: in-person, virtual, and hybrid! This video includes highlights from a handful of recent shows, gives a snapshot of our deep well of capabilities, and showcases the robust FNvirtual Events Platform.

track.name: Sponsor Stories
track.description: Short 10 minute presentations provided by the sponsors.

venue.name: Virtual Only
venue.description: Activities and Events only found on virtual website.

speakers.title: CEO
speakers.bio:
Jeremy has over 25 years of experience in the event industry. In 1996, he and his business partner Chad Kropke founded FNTECH in a small shop in Huntington Beach, CA. Bob Moe soon joined them and together they grew FNTECH into a full-service production company with multiple locations, over 100 fulltime employees and millions in revenue. Jeremy began his career in production as an audio engineer and quickly moved up the ladder to technical director, project manager, and finally executive producer. Having a deep well of experience executing high-profile, multi-million dollar events all over the world, some with more than 120,000 in attendance, we can safely say that there’s a blue moon in the sky when Jeremy is surprised by anything event related.

Jeremy, his beloved guitar, and his stack of super-secret nerd books currently reside in Southern California with his wife and daughter.
